awd_abstract_narration:
Relativistic nuclear collision experiments explore interactions of quarks and gluons, the elementary particles that feel the strong nuclear force. Since the strong force is much stronger than the electromagnetic force, improving our understanding could drive the future frontiers of technology. The Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider (RHIC) and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) collide nuclei together at nearly the speed of light to create a hot and dense soup of quarks and gluons called quark-gluon plasma (QGP). Determining characteristic properties of QGP, like its viscosity or the time it takes to reach equilibrium, is an important way to constrain theories of the strong force. The leading theoretical calculations assume that the strong force rapidly drives the QGP toward equilibrium, but if this is not true in the experimental systems there will be a misinterpretation of the measured characteristic properties. This project focuses on theoretical methods for modeling the expansion and cooling of QGP, determining if QGP reaches an equilibrium state, and investigating how the interplay of expansion and equilibration will effect measurements. This project has strong emphasis on undergraduate education, and since most physics undergraduates will find careers outside of science, they will apply this education in uncountably many roles in society.

Much interpretation that the medium produced in nuclear collisions is QGP results from the agreement of hydrodynamic models with experimental data. As experimental measurements improve, theories need to include deeper and more detailed physics. Moreover, hydrodynamic models use equations of state emerging from Quantum Chromodynamics calculations of locally equilibrated matter. If the medium is not actually in local equilibrium, then the properties that are inferred by hydrodynamics are not necessarily those of QGP. This project will address these issues by developing theoretical methods of hydrodynamics and kinetic theory to include stochastic effects from local and non-local noise and particle jets. Objectives include (1) deriving evolution equations for two-particle correlation observables that highlight the behaviors of partially equilibrated collision events, (2) investigating the influence of partial equilibration on small systems and Beam Energy Scan collision events at RHIC, (3) investigating how jet interactions could produce medium fluctuations and final state correlations that are distinguishable from those described by initial state or thermal sources, and (4) investigating new observables that distinguish the effects of different physical sources of correlations. This work will establish the first ever active physics research program at Lawrence Technological University and integrate this research activity into undergraduate education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award titled RUI: Relativistic Heavy-Ion Theory supports the PI’s study of nuclear matter colliding at nearly the speed of light. The goal of studying nuclear collisions of this type is to study the nature of the strong nuclear force. Current theories predict that a unique form of matter called Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP) should be created in these collisions. Quarks and gluons are particles that are the fundamental building blocks of nuclear matter and they interact via the strong nuclear force. One of the most successful methods for examining the QGP is to model it like a fluid. Fluid models can then be compared to data to extract properties of the fluid, like viscosity. In normal fluids, viscosity is the result of microscopic interactions of molecules; molecular interactions are governed by electromagnetic forces. In QGP the interactions between particles also cause viscosity, but those interactions are governed by the strong nuclear force. So, fluid models can be used to extract values of quantities like the viscosity of QGP and then quantum theories of the strong force try to explain those values. It is therefore critical to investigate all possible reasons that the values of quantities like viscosity may deviate from expectations. The goals of this project focus both on improving fluid models in areas of known deficiency and on methods for making quantitative estimates of the difference between the conditions expected by models and the conditions in real nuclear collisions.

This project intellectually supported two graduate students who have successfully completed their PhDs. One graduate student worked on a fluid model that takes into account the highly random nature of both the initial moments of the nuclear collision and the microscopic collisions of particles in the fluid. This student showed that the random fluctuations in the QGP leave unique signatures in the data that are not included by all fluid models.

Fluid models generally all need to assume that the QGP is in what’s known as “local thermal equilibrium.” A generalization of this statement is that the model assumes that in the regions of the fluid where the calculation takes place, everything in that region has the same temperature. The second graduate student investigated the consequences of this assumption.  They showed that the deviations of real data with model expectations may be used to estimate a value that indicates how out of equilibrium the collision systems are.

Undergraduate students participated in this project in two ways, by contributing to either the scientific goals or the educational goals. Undergraduates that patriated in the scientific goals contributed by running simulations of nuclear collisions and then by writing computer code to do statistical analysis on the products of the simulations. Specifically, the students calculated some existing statistical quantities measured by experiments and used that experience to also calculate new quantities developed by the PI and collaborators. These quantities were selected for their expected sensitivity to the assumption of local thermal equilibrium of QGP.  Finally, the students demonstrated the relationship between the new and existing quantities. This work not only supported the broader work of the graduate students, but also provided a new method for experimentalists to validate that measurements of different statistical quantities are indeed measured in a consistent manner.

The educational goals of this project were based on preparing undergraduates for participation in scientific research. Freshmen physics majors worked with the PI and were asked to design, build, and analyze data from experiments of their own choosing. Their path is iterative and driven by their own decisions. The students were also expected to present their work to the LTU and local community. This method was later piloted as course by the PI. Student feedback and results were so successful that the Department of Natural Sciences has adopted a modified version of this course as a required introductory course for all incoming physics, chemistry, and biology students.

In total, twelve undergraduate students participated in either the scientific or the educational goals of the proposal or both. Student participants spanned several degree programs including physics, computer science, mathematics, computer engineering, and robotics engineering. Many graduating students have gone on to graduate school in physics, medical physics, and computer science. Others have gone on to roles in industry. All graduates reported that their experiences were a formative part of their training and directly contributed to their entrance to the next parts of their careers.
